body:
- `nvim --version`: NVIM v0.3.7
- Vim (version: ) VIM - Vi IMproved 8.1 (2018 May 18). Pasting does not work at all on Vim
- Operating system/version: OpenSUSE Tumbleweed running Sway (Wayland)
- Terminal name/version: tilix
- `$TERM`: xterm-256-color

### Steps to reproduce using `nvim -u NORC`

Copy some content (e.g. from Firefox) containing mulitple lines. Open nvim in safe mode
```
nvim -u NORC
```
Paste content using `"+P` and notice ^M and the end of each line.

Interestingly, pasting directly from the terminal by entering insert mode and then pasting using shift+ctrl+v pastes the content correctly.

Some other interesting pieces of information from neovim:
```
set ff?
  fileformat=unix 
```
```
set ffs?
  fileformats=unix,dos
```

### Expected behaviour
Lines are pasted to neovim without ^M at the end of each line.

comment_data.body:
What does `:checkhealth provider` say about "Clipboard"?

(I am not seeing this issue)

```
## Clipboard (optional)
  - OK: Clipboard tool found: wl-copy
```

there is also the corresponding `wl-paste` command installed.

I *might* be using the rust version of wl-clipboard (I cant recall if I had moved off from it)

https://github.com/YaLTeR/wl-clipboard-rs

EDIT: Comparing the version I have and what is on github, it seems likely that I am.

I'm pretty sure that this issue didnt exist when I initally started using it though. Its been a relatively recent thing that broke

Might be an issue with wl-copy/wl-paste then.
Check if using "xclip" works for you (which I am using), and/or the raw output of `wl-paste` (using e.g. `| cat -A`).

Code ref: https://github.com/blueyed/neovim/blob/5a7590b46fdb7edfb7b5b56a92a59eda2a95d1a6/runtime/autoload/provider/clipboard.vim#L75-L80

Tried installing the official `wl-clipboard` from OpenSUSEs repos and it had the same issue.

when piping to `cat -A` as you suggested I can see that this is actually a wl-paste issue.

```
wl-paste | cat -A          
 might be using the rust version of wl-clipboard (I cant recall if I had moved off from it)^M$
^M$
https://github.com/YaLTeR/wl-clipboard-rs^M$
^M$
EDIT: Comparing the version I have and what is on github, it seems likely that I am.^M$
^M$
```

Thanks for helping me debug this. Will try and figure it out from `wl-clipboard`s side. You mentioned that you use `xclip` - are you running in wayland as I was not aware that this works there.

I'm not using Wayland.

I think Neovim could / should maybe actually handle this, e.g. by normalizing/removing trailing `\r` (if it turns out to be expected behavior with wl-clipboard itself).
I'm asking other wayland users with neovim to see if they have my same issue on their distribution.

Asked a friend to test this out. He has the same issue when copying from firefox/gedit like I tested.

When we tried copying text from chrome though it worked fine - so it seems like it might be an issue unrelated to neovim. Not sure if you have an opinion about this? Should neovim be stripping out the ^M in these scenarios?

Some more information:
It seems like we only get this issue when copying from wayland applications (e.g. running firefox in wayland, gedit in wayland). Anything running in X does not copy text that then exhibits this issue.

> Should neovim be string out the ^M in these scenarios?

IMHO yes - if it is consistent (every line has it).
Re-opening the issue as it seems there is still some stuff left to discuss. Is there anything you would like to test to check how consistent this is so we could confident with stripping them out?
Does the wayland protocol mandate that apps should add ^M before every linebreak in a text clipboard? Or is this something that wl-clipboard utility does?

> Does the wayland protocol mandate that apps should add ^M before every linebreak in a text clipboard? Or is this something that wl-clipboard utility does?

I'm not sure, I'd have to look into some docs. But it feels like a strange requirement considering carriage returns are mostly used on windows machines.
wl-paste doesn't seem to do any data munging, expect for added final newline, which we already have turned off. https://github.com/bugaevc/wl-clipboard/blob/master/src/wl-paste.c#L198

so this seems to imply that the wayland apps themselves have the `^M` in place.

what I dont understand is why would `^M` be excluded in the case of pasting directly from the terminal then?
Not sure why. The specification doesn't seem to say anything about it. Maybe one could look into e.g. the GTK wayland implementation for hints.

> Interestingly, pasting directly from the terminal by entering insert mode and then pasting using shift+ctrl+v pastes the content correctly.

In that case it is handled by bracketed paste. 

I don't see how we can know whether an incoming paste should be "scrubbed" of undesirable characters.

@MichaelAquilina did you figure it out? I think this is a GTK3 issue, I tried to copy from some Qt5 applications [`QT_QPA_PLATFORM=wayland`] (browser Falkon, text editor FeatherPad) and they didn't have carriage returns. On the other hand GTK3 applications [`GDK_BACKEND=wayland`] (browser Eolie, text editor Geany) did have them.
@NicholasAsimov I'm afraid not. I do think you are right however, this is probably a GTK3 on wayland issue.
Just confirming the issue here on Sway. No issue with the same config on macOS.

@MichaelAquilina @pat-s if someone is interested in a quick workaround while this is not fixed, here is a custom clipboard provider that trims carriage returns on paste. All commands match the current master ([runtime/autoload/provider/clipboard.vim](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/autoload/provider/clipboard.vim#L85)) except `wl-paste` command is piped to `tr`.

Add this to your vimrc:
```vim
" Wayland clipboard provider that strips carriage returns (GTK3 issue).
" This is needed because currently there's an issue where GTK3 applications on
" Wayland contain carriage returns at the end of the lines (this is a root
" issue that needs to be fixed).
let g:clipboard = {
      \   'name': 'wayland-strip-carriage',
      \   'copy': {
      \      '+': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain',
      \      '*': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain --primary',
      \    },
      \   'paste': {
      \      '+': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline | tr -d "\r"')},
      \      '*': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline --primary | tr -d "\r"')},
      \   },
      \   'cache_enabled': 1,
      \ }
```

@NicholasAsimov 
Thanks!

Is there an upstream issue somewhere already?
It would be great to know if that's expected etc.

Note that the bracketed paste handler for TUI (which is different than clipboard) already "scrubs" bytes implicitly: `tui.c:tk_getkeys()` calls libtermkeys' `tk_getkey` which translates various bytes (~~and there does not seem to be a way to avoid this~~ / Edit: queue the raw bytes and skip `tk_getkeys`).
@justinmk your latest patch doesn't affect normal mode pasting (`"+p`), right? The literal CR (`^M`) chars are still pasted?

> @justinmk your latest patch doesn't affect normal mode pasting (`"+p`), right? The literal CR (`^M`) chars are still pasted?

9f81acc doesn't affect `"+` at all. `"+` is clipboard, not "paste" (see `:help paste`). 

I marked this issue as "related" because the symptoms are similar.
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/issues/2307

To add to @NicholasAsimov's workaround, you may only want to remove carriage returns if they occur before a newline. Also, since this is wayland-specific, you can wrap it in a check for the `WAYLAND_DISPLAY` env var:

```vim
if exists('$WAYLAND_DISPLAY')
  " Wayland clipboard provider that strips carriage returns (GTK3 issue).
  " This is needed because currently there's an issue where GTK3 applications on
  " Wayland contain carriage returns at the end of the lines (this is a root
  " issue that needs to be fixed).
  let g:clipboard = {
        \   'name': 'wayland-strip-carriage',
        \   'copy': {
        \      '+': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain',
        \      '*': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain --primary',
        \    },
        \   'paste': {
        \      '+': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline | sed -e "s/\r$//"')},
        \      '*': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline --primary | sed -e "s/\r$//"')},
        \   },
        \   'cache_enabled': 1,
        \ }
endif
```

I used @b0o / @NicholasAsimov's   workarounds here, but with both of them I had problems with a different pasting behaviour. So I asked on stackexchange and got the valuable answer, to add two more arguments to the `systemlist`: https://vi.stackexchange.com/questions/26895/custom-gclipboard-results-in-p-always-pasting-into-the-same-line/26897

So this is my g:clipboard now:

```vim
if exists('$WAYLAND_DISPLAY')
    " clipboard on wayland with newline fix
    let g:clipboard = {
                \   'name': 'WL-Clipboard with ^M Trim',
                \   'copy': {
                \      '+': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain',
                \      '*': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain --primary',
                \    },
                \   'paste': {
                \      '+': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline | sed -e "s/\r$//"', '', 1)},
                \      '*': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline --primary | sed -e "s/\r$//"', '', 1)},
                \   },
                \   'cache_enabled': 1,
                \ }
endif
```

Thanks for these snippets everyone. Just wanted add that these also appear to fix an issue I had where I couldn't copy anything from outside vim that begun with a `--`, I'd got into the habit of always trying to include a space in my selection, so I'd copy `[space]--`. But now this is fixed. I have normal copy pasting again!

Here is a version of the clipboard provider which will only paste plain text, giving **E353: Nothing in register** if non-text content is in the clipboard. This will prevent any binary content from being damaged by the newline fix.

```viml
if exists('$WAYLAND_DISPLAY')
    " clipboard on wayland with newline fix
    let g:clipboard = {
        \   'name': 'WL-Clipboard with ^M Trim',
        \   'copy': {
        \      '+': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain',
        \      '*': 'wl-copy --foreground --type text/plain --primary',
        \    },
        \   'paste': {
        \      '+': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline --type "text/plain;charset=utf-8" 2>/dev/null | sed -e "s/\r$//"', '', 1)},
        \      '*': {-> systemlist('wl-paste --no-newline --type "text/plain;charset=utf-8" --primary 2>/dev/null | sed -e "s/\r$//"', '', 1)},
        \   },
        \   'cache_enabled': 1,
        \ }
endif
```

A [fix](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1547595#c46) for this issue was included in Firefox 81. Not sure about other GTK apps. I've happily removed the clipboard workaround from my vimrc because it was messing with pasting after yanking in visual block mode.
@justinmk was this actually fixed for pasting using `wl-paste`? I'm still seeing this problem.

I have got the same issue when pasting using `p` command from a Microsoft Excel cell to Neovim. I got `^M` at the end of each line. However, pasting the same content to Vim 8.0, it was pasted normally.  

I am on the following version of NVIM:
```
NVIM v0.5.1
Build type: Release
LuaJIT 2.1.0-beta3
Compilation: clang -U_FORTIFY_SOURCE -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=1 -DNVIM_TS_HAS_SET_MATCH_LIMIT -O2 -DNDEBUG -Wall -Wextra -pedantic -Wno-unused-parameter -Wstrict-prototypes -std=gnu99 -Wshadow -Wconversion -Wmissing-prototypes -Wimplicit-fallthrough -Wvla -fstack-protector-strong -fno-common -fdiagnostics-color=auto -DINCLUDE_GENERATED_DECLARATIONS -D_GNU_SOURCE -DNVIM_MSGPACK_HAS_FLOAT32 -DNVIM_UNIBI_HAS_VAR_FROM -DMIN_LOG_LEVEL=3 -I/tmp/neovim-20211103-3501-1gz0ofb/neovim-0.5.1/build/config -I/tmp/neovim-20211103-3501-1gz0ofb/neovim-0.5.1/src -I/usr/local/include -I/tmp/neovim-20211103-3501-1gz0ofb/neovim-0.5.1/deps-build/include -I/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX11.sdk/usr/include -I/usr/local/opt/gettext/include -I/tmp/neovim-20211103-3501-1gz0ofb/neovim-0.5.1/build/src/nvim/auto -I/tmp/neovim-20211103-3501-1gz0ofb/neovim-0.5.1/build/include
Compiled by brew@BigSur
```

I'm running this issue using Windows Subsystem for Linux. My current workaround is this command in my vimrc:

    command! Slinefeed :%s/\r//

:Slinefeed

title: Neovim pasting content with ^M at the end of lines
